mn12:2.1: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar
mn12:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī in a woodland grove behind the town.
mn12:3.3: Now at that time Sunakkhatta the Licchavi had recently left this teaching and training.
mn12:3.4: He was telling a crowd in Vesālī:
mn12:3.5: “The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
mn12:3.6: He teaches what he’s worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing his own perspective.
mn12:3.7: And his teaching leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it’s taught.”
mn12:4.1: Then Venerable Sāriputta got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, entered Vesālī for alms.
mn12:4.2: He heard what Sunakkhatta was saying.
mn12:5.1: Then he wandered for alms in Vesālī. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha,
mn12:5.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
mn12:5.3: and told him what had happened.
mn12:6.1: “Sāriputta, Sunakkhatta, that foolish man, is angry.
mn12:6.2: His words are spoken out of anger.
mn12:6.3: Thinking to criticize the Realized One, in fact he just praises him.
mn12:6.4: For it is praise of the Realized One to say:
mn12:6.5: ‘His Dhamma leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it’s taught.’
mn12:7.1: But there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:
mn12:7.2: ‘That Blessed One is perfect, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of people, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
mn12:8.1: And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:
mn12:8.2: ‘That Blessed One wields the many kinds of psychic power:
mn12:8.3: multiplying himself and becoming one again;
mn12:8.5: going unimpeded through a wall, an embankment, or a mountain as if through space;
mn12:8.6: diving in and out of the earth as if it was water;
mn12:8.7: walking on water as if it was earth;
mn12:8.8: flying cross-legged through the air like a bird;
mn12:8.9: touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful;
mn12:8.10: controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm.’
mn12:9.1: And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:
mn12:9.2: ‘That Blessed One, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, hears both kinds of sounds,
mn12:9.3: human and divine, whether near or far.’
mn12:10.1: And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:
mn12:10.2: ‘That Blessed One understands the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with his own mind.
mn12:10.3: He understands mind with greed as “mind with greed”, and mind without greed as “mind without greed”.
mn12:10.4: He understands mind with hate … mind without hate …
mn12:10.5: mind with delusion … mind without delusion …
mn12:10.8: mind that is supreme … mind that is not supreme …
mn12:10.10: freed mind as “freed mind”, and unfreed mind as “unfreed mind”.’
mn12:11.1: A Realized One has these ten powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.
mn12:12.1: Firstly, a Realized One truly understands the possible as possible, and the impossible as impossible.
mn12:12.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a Realized One’s power. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lions roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.
mn12:13.1: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the result of deeds undertaken in the past, future, and present in terms of causes and reasons.
mn12:13.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a Realized One’s power. …

mn12:14.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a Realized One’s power. …

mn12:15.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a Realized One’s power. …
mn12:16.1: Furthermore, a Realized One truly understands the diverse beliefs of sentient beings.
mn12:16.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a Realized One’s power. …
mn12:17.1: Furthermore, a Realized One truly understands the faculties of other sentient beings and other individuals after comprehending them with his mind.
mn12:17.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a Realized One’s power. …
mn12:18.1: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands corruption, cleansing, and emergence regarding the absorptions, liberations, convergences, and attainments.
mn12:18.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a Realized One’s power. …
mn12:19.1: Furthermore, the Realized One recollects many kinds of past lives, that is,
mn12:19.2: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand lives; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world evolving, many eons of the world contracting and evolving. He remembers:
mn12:19.3: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else.
mn12:19.4: There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’
mn12:19.5: And so he recollects his many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
mn12:19.6: Since he truly understands this, this is a Realized One’s power. …
mn12:20.1: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Realized One sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
mn12:20.2: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
mn12:20.3: These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’
mn12:20.4: And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, he sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
mn12:20.5: Since he truly understands this, this is a Realized One’s power. …
mn12:21.1: Furthermore, the Realized One has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having achieved it with his own insight due to the end of defilements.
mn12:21.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a Realized One’s power. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lions roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.

mn12:34.3: Reproduction for creatures born from an egg, from a womb, from moisture, or spontaneously.

mn12:34.5: There are beings who are born by breaking out of an eggshell.

mn12:34.8: There are beings who are born by breaking out of the amniotic sac.
mn12:34.9: This is called reproduction from a womb.
mn12:34.10: And what is reproduction from moisture?
mn12:34.11: There are beings who are born in a rotten fish, in a rotten corpse, in rotten dough, in a cesspool or a sump.

mn12:37.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand:
mn12:37.2: ‘This person is practicing in such a way and has entered such a path that when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’
mn12:37.3: Then some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in hell, where they experience exclusively painful feelings, sharp and severe.
mn12:37.4: Suppose there was a pit of glowing coals deeper than a man’s height, full of glowing coals that neither flamed nor smoked.
mn12:37.5: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. But the path they’re on heads in one direction only, to that very same pit of coals.
mn12:37.6: If person with good eyesight saw him they’d say:
mn12:37.7: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and has entered such a path that they will arrive at that very pit of coals.’
mn12:37.8: Then some time later they see that they have indeed fallen into that pit of coals, where they experience exclusively painful feelings, sharp and severe. …

mn12:44.1: Sāriputta, I recall having practiced a spiritual path consisting of four factors.
mn12:44.2: I used to be a self-mortifier, the ultimate self-mortifier. I used to live rough, the ultimate rough liver. I used to be a shunner, the ultimate shunner. I used to be secluded, in ultimate seclusion.
mn12:44.3: And this is what my self-mortification was like. I went naked, ignoring conventions. I licked my hands, and didn’t come or stop when asked.
mn12:44.4: I didn’t consent to food brought to me, or food prepared on purpose for me, or an invitation for a meal.
mn12:44.5: I didn’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breast-feeding, or who has a man in her home; or where food for distribution is advertised; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing.
mn12:44.6: I accepted no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drank no beer.
mn12:44.7: I went to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to
mn12:44.10: I fed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to
mn12:44.13: I ate once a day, once every second day, up to
mn12:44.16: and so on, even up to once a fortnight. I lived committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
mn12:45.1: I ate herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. I survived on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
mn12:46.1: I wore robes of hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
mn12:46.2: I tore out hair and beard, committed to this practice.
mn12:46.4: I squatted, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
mn12:46.5: I lay on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns my bed.
mn12:46.6: I was committed to the practice of immersion in water three times a day, including the evening.
mn12:46.7: And so I lived committed to practicing these various ways of torturing and tormenting the body.
mn12:46.8: Such was my practice of self-mortification.
mn12:47.1: And this is what my rough living was like.
mn12:47.2: The dust and dirt built up on my body over many years until it started flaking off.
mn12:47.3: It’s like the trunk of a pale-moon ebony tree, which builds up bark over many years until it starts flaking off.

mn12:48.1: And this is what my practice of shunning was like.
mn12:48.2: I’d step forward or back ever so mindfully. I was full of pity even regarding a drop of water, thinking:
mn12:48.3: ‘May I not accidentally injure any little creatures that happen to be in the wrong place.’
mn12:48.4: Such was my practice of shunning.
mn12:49.1: And this is what my seclusion was like.
mn12:49.2: I would plunge deep into a wilderness region and stay there.
mn12:49.3: When I saw a cowherd or a shepherd, or someone gathering grass or sticks, or a lumberjack, I’d flee from forest to forest, from thicket to thicket, from valley to valley, from uplands to uplands.
mn12:49.5: So that I wouldn’t see them, nor they me.
mn12:49.6: I fled like a wild deer seeing a human being.
mn12:49.10: Such was my practice of seclusion.
mn12:50.1: I would go on all fours into the cow-pens after the cattle had left and eat the dung of the young suckling calves.
mn12:50.2: As long as my own urine and excrement lasted, I would even eat that.
mn12:50.3: Such was my eating of most unnatural things.

mn12:54.19: and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn.
mn12:54.21: Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.

mn12:56.3: Because I didn’t achieve that noble wisdom that’s noble and emancipating, and which leads someone who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
mn12:57.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn12:57.3: But it’s not easy to find any realm that I haven’t previously transmigrated to in all this long time, except for the gods of the pure abodes.
mn12:57.4: For if I had transmigrated to the gods of the pure abodes I would not have returned to this realm again.
mn12:58.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn12:58.3: But it’s not easy to find any rebirth that I haven’t previously been reborn in …
mn12:59.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn12:59.3: But it’s not easy to find an abode that I haven’t previously abided in …
mn12:60.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn12:60.3: But it’s not easy to find a sacrifice that I haven’t previously offered in all this long time, when I was an anointed king or a propertied brahmin.
mn12:61.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn12:61.2: ‘Purity comes from worshiping the sacred flame.’
mn12:61.3: But it’s not easy to find a fire that I haven’t previously worshiped in all this long time, when I was an anointed king or a propertied brahmin.
mn12:62.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
mn12:62.2: ‘So long as this gentleman is youthful, young, black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life he will be endowed with perfect proficiency in wisdom.
mn12:62.3: But when he’s old, elderly, and senior, has lived long and reached the final stage of life—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—he will lose his proficiency in wisdom.’
mn12:62.4: But you should not see it like this.
mn12:62.5: For now I am old, elderly, and senior, I’ve lived long and reached the final stage of life. I am eighty years old.
mn12:62.6: Suppose I had four disciples with a lifespan of a hundred years. And they each were perfect in memory, range, retention, and perfect proficiency in wisdom.
mn12:62.7: Imagine how easily a well-trained expert archer with a strong bow would shoot a light arrow across the shadow of a palm tree. That’s how extraordinary they were in memory, range, retention, and perfect proficiency in wisdom.
mn12:62.8: They’d bring up questions about the four kinds of mindfulness meditation again and again, and I would answer each question. They’d remember the answers and not ask the same question twice.
mn12:62.9: And they’d pause only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness. But the Realized One would not run out of Dhamma teachings, words and phrases of the teachings, or spontaneous answers.
mn12:62.10: And at the end of a hundred years my four disciples would pass away.
mn12:62.11: Even if you have to carry me around on a stretcher, there will never be any deterioration in the Realized One’s proficiency in wisdom.
mn12:62.12: And if there’s anyone of whom it should be rightly said that
mn12:62.13: a being not liable to delusion has arisen in the world for the welfare and happiness of many people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans, it’s of me that this should be said.”
mn12:63.1: Now at that time Venerable Nāgasamāla was standing behind the Buddha fanning him.
mn12:63.2: Then he said to the Buddha:
mn12:63.4: While I was listening to this explanation of the teaching my hair stood up!
mn12:63.5: What is the name of this explanation of the teaching?”
mn12:63.6: “Well, Nāgasamāla, you may remember this explanation of the teaching as ‘The Hair-raising Discourse’.”
mn12:64.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn12:64.2: Uplifted, Venerable Nāgasamāla approved of what the Buddha said.
